docs.title: The Vault of Penance
docs.text:
Description
  • Location: Beneath the central cathedral of Hellhaven, with entrances heavily guarded by the [[Creosmagi]].
  • Structure: A labyrinthine, multi-tiered vault descending deep into the earth, each level serving a distinct function.
  • Purpose:
    • Imprisonment – Holding heretics, dissidents, and rogue mages.
  • Artifact Containment – Storing and studying arcane relics too dangerous for public knowledge.
  • Repentance & Trial – Torture chambers, confession halls, and execution sites for those deemed irredeemable.
  • Buried Depths – Sealed chambers that predate [[The Lord]]’s rule, containing forgotten history, horrors, and mysteries.
Lore

The Vault of Penance is a vast subterranean complex beneath Hellhaven, serving as both a prison and a sanctified repository for arcane artifacts deemed heretical by the clergy. It is where the [[Creosmagi]] incarcerates those accused of sorcery, blasphemy, or defiance against The Creed of Binding Light. It is also a site of secretive research, as scholars of the church attempt to repurpose dangerous relics for the theocracy’s benefit. The deeper levels, abandoned to the ages, are rumored to hold ancient pre-theocratic ruins, long-forgotten heresies, and prisoners who have been erased from history.

Current Events

docs.title: 1. The Inquisition’s Hold
docs.text:
• The Vault of Penance is the jurisdiction of Archprelate of Binds [[Rhaeven Marciel]], a zealous enforcer of divine law.
  • Prisoners undergo brutal interrogations, with forced confessions being a common outcome.
  • Some inmates are released as broken converts, while others are executed or simply vanish into the lower depths.

docs.title: 2. The Relic Crypts
docs.text:
• The church hoards magical artifacts in the vaults, seeking to either purify or repurpose them.
  • Many items are unstable, their power restrained by wards and sigils.
  • Certain factions within the clergy argue over the ethics of wielding such relics rather than destroying them.

docs.title: 3. The Forgotten Depths
docs.text:
• The lower levels contain remnants of Gellhafn’s past, sealed away after [[The Dread]].
  • It is rumored that something old and unsanctioned stirs in the depths, beyond even the Inquisition’s reach.
  • The deepest chambers are uncharted, lost to time, superstition, and the deaths of those who dared to explore.

docs.title: 4. The Whispered Rebellion
docs.text:
• Some imprisoned mages and scholars work in secret to escape or overthrow their captors.
  • Smugglers and rogue clerics leak information from within, offering a glimpse into the church’s darkest secrets.
  • The Vault may be more than just a prison—it could be a ticking time bomb of suppressed knowledge and rising dissent.

docs.title: Dealing Manor
docs.text:
Location and Description

Notable Residents

History and Lore

Scornubel, Thomas Buckenbridge asks Agatha for a son, Saliba Weistan is born on the 15th of Kythorn

Ashnei Darkwind, Astera Glasciasare, [[Daewynn Hithglad]], Evanescence of Waterdeep, & Venarious Sullac seek out the power of the hag for various reasons. The first three made a pact to betray the others and their wish was promised to be granted if they were the last standing. Evanescence and Ashnei broke their pact with Agatha, Evanescence and Venarious were slain by Daewynn, who was slain shortly after by Ashnei and his own folly.

Venarious and Daewynn were resurrected by Agatha, and begins to honor her pact with Daewynn, granting fae power and training in arcane necromancy. Agatha grows changelings in the cellar, and abducts a child in Beregost named Annabelle.

Agatha works for REDACTED, the reason why she spreads suffering wherever she goes through her deals. Daewynn has begun to realize that they have exhausted the hag's knowledge and began to work behind her back to overthrow her position in the pact with REDACTED. After contacting REDACTED through Agatha's ritual, he killed Agatha and sealed the pact with her essence. REDACTED leads him to transport the Manor to Gwynneth and begin summoning dark fey to assault Sarifal. Daewynn used his infiltrating fey to spread rumors about a hag named Annabelle that lived in a certain "Dealing Manor" where the fey originated from. Maybe it's actually what the summoned fey believe. It's a slow war, one of espionage and intrigue, and will last many years.

Prince Araithe of Sarifal goes on a scourge through the Winterglen, striking down any resistance that he encounters. REDACTED leads Daewynn to temporarily transport the Manor to the Neverwinter Forest to assist a Nothic in summoning and binding an Alkilith to the trellis entrance to Varienne's cottage. During this time, REDACTED approaches Dealing Manor in search of someone to help him soil the REDACTED family name, so Daewynn, not having any time to teach him anything, teleports him to REDACTED's tower in the Underdark, much to REDACTED's chagrin. .... REDACTED ...

Daewynn returns the Dealing Manor to Winterglen and continues fulfilling their pact with REDACTED by building a dark fae army in response to Prince Araithe's and the Keepers of the Fractured Ruby's boldness. Establishing a permanent feycrossing by contaminating a REDACTED with REDACTED's magic.
Events of the Dealing Manor sidequest occur.

docs.title: Agatha's Bedroom
docs.text:
It is a simple room with beige patterned wallpaper and a large bed. In the room there is a chest requiring a key. Inside the chest, it is full of paintings (or photographs if that’s cool) of little girls, just hundreds, maybe thousands. They all stretch across different time periods. - With a thorough investigation, one can find a picture with a red circle around it of a girl with blond hair and green eyes. In the room is a vanity mirror, and when one does an arcana check, they can find that it is a portal to another realm. - Attempting to enter would result in a level of madness. A standing wardrobe contains nothing but human-length mirrors, on the inside walls and the inside of the doors. A character's reflection will be how Daewynn speaks to the character for a deal. Touching the mirror results in releasing a reflection, one of the souls trapped within the Manor's own demiplane.

On top of the bed, one could reach a handle leading to the attic.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. Laying down in bed will send a character tumbling through space and landing in the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Puzzle Room, covered in sheets and lace, and partially undressed, a little joke of Daewynn's own design.

docs.title: Annabelle's Room
docs.text:
It is a typical child’s room with a small bed and stuffed animals everywhere, but a few notable items. There is a cat stuffed animal with the left eye ripped out and a dog stuffed animal hidden carefully under the bed. There is a small shelf with a few books, one notable one being Hansel and Gretel. - Inside one of the pages is a note that reads “it gave me this book, does it want to eat me?” There is an art easel with some old paintings on it. - There are some very beautiful ones signed by Wynrose Halifact. As the paintings are looked through, a noticeable drop in quality happens. The brush strokes are messy and unpracticed. - On one painting, there is a signature crossed out and instead replaced with the signature of Wynrose Halifact, but the penmanship does not match. - One last painting is found, a winding creature in black and white seen wrapping around cities, a face melting into its own spindly body. Written below is “it tells me to call it mother”

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. This room leads to another locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway, which can be seen partially by looking underneath Wynrose's bed.

docs.title: Attic
docs.text:
Upon entering the attic, one would find a wisp, the soul of a young girl. She will attack if touched or provoked, but can be won over persuasively by being reminded of her life as Wynrose Halifact. - If given mercy, she will give details on the entity and some of Annabelle’s life here in the manor.

This is the separated soul of who Annabelle used to be before being turned into a hag by Agatha. Annabelle does not recognize the name Wynrose Halifact and has forgotten her memories before the separation.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. A circular window in the roof looks into a long locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway, which can be accessed through such.

docs.title: Bathroom
docs.text:
Use as needed, but there is blond and silver hair able to be found in the bathroom.

A psychic grey ooze lives in disguise as the mortaring in the walls. If a character stalls for too long in this room, it will attack.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. Once a piece of Annabelle's hair is found, it burns away in green flame and teleports the holder to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Puzzle Room.

docs.title: Courtyard
docs.text:
Rain-soaked grass lies before you with a smattering of puddles that reflect rippled and distorted views of the outer manor walls that rise up from every direction. A fountain stands motionless in the center, a circular stone base that comes up to the hip holds cloudy water. Several heaps litter the surrounding area, and on closer inspection of the one nearest you, they seem to be the rotting corpses of those who have passed through here once before. The moisture in the air only worsens the stench, and you find yourself covering your mouth and nose instinctually.

Inside the dormant water fountain lies a Lampad in waiting. If the water is disturbed, the Lampad will grapple a character and transport it to a nearby corpse, where Daewynn will speak to them through.

An area within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. Exiting from where they came will lead a character to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Puzzle Room.

docs.title: Dining Hall
docs.text:
A long dark table runs the length of the room right to left, where the at the end of the room a short staircase leads up to a solitary carved-framed door. On the other side of the room in the back corner is a simple wooden swinging door. The chairs at the table are filled with skeletons dressed in various garb, filling all of the seats except for the two chairs on either head of the table. Each skeleton is poised to appear to have been frozen mid-meal. Several low, empty pedestals line the floor along each of the walls parallel to the table. - If one of the players is an undead race, the skeletons will be friendly and not attack, instead reveal that the hag makes deals with all her guests and turns them on each other for an evil has corrupted her.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. The swinging door leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Kitchen. The lone door past the stairs leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway.

docs.title: Foyer
docs.text:
• Renee Description: A large room in the shape of an octagon lies unassuming. Two staircases rise from either side of the entrance, leading to an overlooking balcony. There are torches on the walls burning an everlasting light, the green flames flickering as though alive themselves. Paintings line both levels, works of art displaying haughty and arrogant folks. A man with a long, twisted moustache smokes a cigar as he dully looks forward (Thomas Halifact). To his right is a woman with long blonde hair, smiling pointlessly forward, seeing past and maybe beyond (Sarah Halifact). A few tables lay about along with a dusty old piano situated solemnly against the rightmost wall and the leftmost wall is covered by a bookshelf.
    • The bookshelf can be moved, revealing the entrance to the catacombs.
    • Behind one of the paintings is a phrase "Where the sun doesn't shine but the moon is bright, I see only grey as I run out of time."

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. A doorway in the center of the balcony leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway. Doors underneath the balcony to the left and right lead to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Library and locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Dining Hall, respectively.

docs.title: Front Entrance
docs.text:
Renee Description: The manor is a looming, lonely vessel. The windows are all boarded up and the door is locked, albeit made of weak and molding wood. There are empty gardens, barren of any signs of life. All of it seems to have crawled up the manor itself, entwining itself with the wood and stone details.

Any players that roll below a Quickling's intiative will be subjected to some possible theivery.

A Nightstalker roams the woods outside.

An area within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. This leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Foyer, but there is also an entrance in the woods to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Sewers.

docs.title: Hallway
docs.text:
The hallway is as simple as it gets, but there is something haunting about it. Rows of armor line the hallway, most seeming to be charred, tarnished or torn. Upon inspection, one set of armor will have the words “T.H.” engraved in it, and another will have “S.H.” engraved. Windows are scattered in between each display, the patter of rain persistent in its assault on the glass. Flashes of light in the clouds threaten to bring raucous thunder.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. At the end of the hall is a door, which has an equal chance of leading a character to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Bathroom, locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Agatha's Bedroom, the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Courtyard, and the Hallway again. Ruz will be sent to a pocket plane within the Manor's domain and converse with Yphrhei itself to make a deal and receive instructions. He will reappear when convenient.

The hallway may also be accessed through a round window from the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Attic, entering the hallway by breaking in from the outside. The hallway then only continues on to locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Annabelle's Room, no matter which side you leave from.

After exiting Annabelle's Room, the hall then leads to either the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Sewers or the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Roof Garden.

docs.title: Kitchen
docs.text:
A kitchen, far cleaner than the rest of the house. There is a small table, a wood oven, a few marble counters, some cabinets underneath, and an icebox. A slotted pantry door stands in the wall to the left. - Opening the cabinet where Venarious Sullac used to be (skeleton?) would cause an alarm to sound off, summoning monsters from the back room. In the oven, one would find a picture of a child, carefully drawn with the eyes scribbled out. The icebox is full of fresh meat of an “indiscernible source.” - An arcana check would reveal it has magic origins. - Opening the cabinet with let out a small group of Darklings that had been living there.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. The icebox sits ontop of a trapdoor that leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Puzzle Room. The "pantry" leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway.

docs.title: Laboratory
docs.text:
Several wooden shelves hang from chains in the ceiling, bearing various jars of sickly yellow, brown, and green hues, holding various organs and biological samples of indiscernible origin from this distance. A hooded figure is hunched over a work table lit by a small candle, but most of the light in the room comes from a furnace in the back, on top of which bubbles a cauldron and a ladle that is stirring on its own. What looks to be a jail door leads off to the right.

The hooded figure is an Indentured Spirit, and one of the jars on the suspended shelves is a Brain in a Jar.

An area within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. It can only be accessed by navigating the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Sewers. The metal barred door leads to locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/The Grove.

docs.title: Library
docs.text:
Upon arriving upstairs, the characters will be met with a vast maze of shelves. There are books on child raising, self help books, spell books, necromancy, magic of clerics, and a book simply titled “The Entity” (SEE LORE PAGE). There is a painting on the floor leaning up against the wall. On it is the picture of the man and woman from earlier paintings, as well as a young girl with blond hair and blue eyes. In her arms is a small kitten.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. There are 2 doors, each requiring an Intelligence (Investigation) check, the left one leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Study, and the back one leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway.

docs.title: Puzzle Room
docs.text:
A large room in the shape of a square, with a slightly lifted platform of a square. On the platform is a 3 by 3 grid made of weighted tiles. The pattern is as follows: In the room, a strange heaviness lays in the air. There is something in the room that cannot be seen (I mean, like, the dc is a 25 for arcana or religion). It sees the adventurers though. Upon solving the puzzle correctly (Characters standing on the BLACK SUN, WHITE MOON, GREY CIRCLE, BLACK HOURGLASS), a countdown will occur throughout the room starting at 20. Upon running out of time, the door at the end of the room that was locked shut will open, revealing the way to the upper level.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. After the puzzle is solved, the door's aura dissipates, and walking through will lead the characters to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Attic.

docs.title: Roof Garden
docs.text:
A showdown for the ages. The garden is much more alive than the one outside the mansion. The hag awaits there. The battle can go one of many ways. 1. Everyone turns on each other because of the deals set up (if gone down that path). The hag will watch in delighted amusement with her rat friends, eating a bucket of eyeballs like popcorn and throwing out quips or weird suggestions. 2. Everyone fights against the hag. 3. You can “save” the hag through persuasion checks. By revealing the past of Annabelle, you are able to make persuasion checks and bring back the hag’s memories and restore her humanity. The amount of successful checks is up to the dm. However, if the players get 3 rolls 5 and under, the hag will unleash The Entity. 4. The party splits, those that break their pact suffer the consequences and the ones who adhere to it will be respected by the owner of the Manor, who may even help in the fight.

An area within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. This battle will take place in the Manor's demiplane, as Annabelle will put all the characters to sleep to astral project into a demiplane that appears to take place in the Moonshae Isles, but on a much smaller scale, as characters tower over the isles and conduct their battle there. This area can only be accessed in the final iteration of the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway.

docs.title: Sewers
docs.text:
Far off to the left of the manor, in the foggy woods one may find a cellar door, seemingly randomly. Entering would reveal catacombs, dank and wet with the scent of mildew. Traversing through the catacombs would lead one into the foyer of the manor. In the catacombs, if one is perfectly perceptive, they may even catch a glimpse of a young girl with blonde hair and green eyes.

The entire sewer and pathway system beneath the manor is infested with shadows of souls captured by the owners of the Manor.

An area within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. An exit leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Front Entrance and deeper in lies the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Laboratory.

docs.title: Study
docs.text:
The study is a small room absolutely torn up. It looks as if animals were let in and tore the place up. The sofa is ripped and the stuffing from the pillows lay about. All paintings in the room have tears that make them mangled and barely hanging to the frame. - Some mending spells would reveal that it is family paintings, with the man and woman from the foyer paintings holding a small baby. - In the desk, one would find a letter in an envelope, the edges burnt. The letter reads, “I appreciate hearing from you, Mykahni. It’s been two months since Wynrose died, and Sarah is not improving. She has gone mad with grief, for I see her talking to the walls themselves, begging for our daughter back. She claims there is something there, something I cannot see. It must be hysteria, but sometimes when I’m especially tired, I see a glimpse of black and white, creeping on the-” and the rest is torn off.

If the players make enough noise while searching through this room, or if they search through the pillows strewn around the floor, it will wake the family cat. This poor pet was experimented on by Agatha and it has since mutated into a beastly-looking grey-haired meenlock.

A room within the Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. On the right side of the room stands a wooden display case with glass shelving and a mirror back. This stands upon a short set of wooden cabinets, which lead to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Hallway if crawled through. A door at the opposite wall from the entrance is blocked by a pile of pillows, under which lies a sleeping meenlock, as described above. This door leads to the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Puzzle Room.

docs.title: The Grove
docs.text:
The room opens up to a natural cavern, several columns reach from the floor to ceiling, glistening black things that seem to pulse and contract every few seconds. The floor is covered in large piles of bramble, about 20 of them, with grey woody vines covered in thorns and adorned with a smattering of white leaves on each of the piles. After each contraction of the pillars, the brambles' leaves shudder, as if they were breathing. The room is alive with unnatural energy, and you intuitively recognize you are in the presence of an abhorrent mockery of life.

This is where Agatha once and Daewynn now grows their changelings, bred for infiltration and societal deadliness. The pillars are the influence of "the Entity," the being that holds Yphrhei hostage in the Feywild.

This area is a location in Locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Dealing Manor. It can only be accessed through the locations/Landmarks/Establishments/Dealing Manor/Manor Locations/Laboratory.

Description

Residents

Species Contour History and Lore

docs.title: The Sunforged Coliseum
docs.text:
Location and Description

A large coliseum located in the heart of the city, with large archways allowing hoards of spectators to enter through. Detailed stone work can be found on every wall and column, evoking ancient draconic imagery. The arena itself hosts rows upon rows of seating, enough to host thousands of attendants. High up there are various guest boxes reserved for the most wealthy members of draconic society. An announcer's box is amongst these, magically equipped to allow the users voice to be heard amongst the roaring crowds.

At the center of this massive coliseum is a large circular arena with a sandy floor. Four bared entrances lead into the fighting pit, a large moat circling it, with draconic fountains jutting out of the walls. Small bridges with snake head railings allow the competitors passage to the center of the arena. Twelve fifty foot columns of rough stone topped with fire line up around the arena. Large stone crocodile statues, standing rearing on their hide quarters, provide platforms for competitors to take their starting positions on.

Bellow the arena hosts the competitors, and their rooms for preparation. A vast armory of magical weaponry and tools are available to them. Along with medics and staff on hand to attend to any injuries that befall them while in the arena.

Competitors

History and Lore

docs.title: Invention
docs.text: Empir Draconi was a hub of ingenuity, blending arcane mastery with practical engineering. The empire pioneered advancements in levitation technology, adaptive metallurgy, and elemental energy manipulation. Many of these innovations revolved around the needs of their floating cities, war efforts, and trade networks.

docs.title: Distribution
docs.text: The empire’s economy depended on a structured resource distribution network. Floating cities relied on docking settlements and ground-based provinces for raw materials, while centralized bureaucracies managed supply chains with magical oversight.

docs.title: Imports
docs.text:
Despite its self-sufficiency, Empir Draconi imported specialized resources, including:

  • Rare minerals from deep-earth mines and neighboring nations.
  • Exotic alchemical reagents traded from distant lands.
  • Luxury textiles woven from foreign arcane silks.

docs.title: Income
docs.text:
The empire's wealth flowed from multiple avenues, including:

  • Taxation of settlements and guilds.
  • Arcane trade in spellwork, artifacts, and energy refinement.
  • Military conquest and subjugation, seizing assets from lesser nations.
  • Guild monopolies over essential crafts, enforced through imperial decree.

docs.title: Key Industries
docs.text:
Aethercrafting

The refinement and shaping of aetherstone and other levitation materials, crucial for maintaining the floating cities.

Elemental Energy Harnessing

Extraction and containment of raw elemental forces for power sources and weaponry.

Artificing and Enchantment

The empire's skilled artificers infused weapons, armor, and tools with arcane properties, leading to a booming enchanted goods trade.

Draconic Alchemy

Harnessing dragon blood, scales, and essence for medicinal, magical, and military applications.

docs.title: Niche Professions
docs.text:
Fabric Engineers

Experts who studied and manipulated [[The Arras]] to stabilize floating cities and arcane structures.

Skybound Merchants

Traders specializing in high-altitude commerce, piloting wind-skiffs and aerial caravans between cities.

Rune-Scribes

Scholars and artisans who engraved arcane runes into tools, weapons, and architecture to enhance their properties.

Tidecallers

Mages who regulated water flow to prevent oceanic disasters before the empire’s fall.

docs.title: Mundane Professions
docs.text:
• Blacksmiths
  • Farmers
  • Dockworkers
  • Merchants
  • Scribes
  • Architects
  • Leatherworkers
  • Tailors
  • Street Performers

docs.title: Companies
docs.text:
Several powerful trade syndicates and noble-backed enterprises controlled different sectors of the economy:

  • The Gilded Wyrm Consortium – A merchant guild overseeing the trade of enchanted goods and arcane relics.
  • Draconis Aetherworks – The empire’s leading manufacturer of aetherstone-based technologies.
  • The Obsidian Exchange – A financial institution managing imperial wealth and high-value transactions.
  • The Talon Forges – A state-backed weapons manufacturer specializing in enchanted arms for the military.
  • The Azure Loom – A luxury textile company producing enchanted fabrics for nobility and spellcasters alike.

docs.title: Layout
docs.text: Empir Draconi was born from the unity of warring states upon a vast island kingdom, an expanse of fertile land and volcanic peaks surrounded by the temperamental sea. The empire’s heart lay in the capital, a city of towering basalt citadels and grand avenues paved with polished obsidian. From this center of power, emperors and the Magisterium ruled with calculated authority, their dominion stretching outward through fortified ports, sprawling agricultural terraces, and mining colonies rich with precious ores.

docs.title: Planning
docs.text: While the floating cities became the pride of the empire, the land itself remained its foundation. The empire's mainland domains, including its annexed territories and coastal fortresses, provided the resources necessary for its continued expansion. The grand roads, paved with arcane-reinforced stone, connected its provinces, ensuring the swift movement of legions, goods, and imperial decrees. These regions were governed by high lords and imperial magistrates, maintaining order and enforcing the will of the emperor.

docs.title: Districts
docs.text:
Empir Draconi’s dominion was vast, divided into distinct regions, each serving a crucial role:

  • The Imperial Heartland – The ruling seat of the empire, housing the Magisterium, the emperor’s palace, and the grand arenas of law and war.

  • The Celestial Bastions – The floating cities, each a self-sufficient entity hosting scholars, military garrisons, and the elite of society.

  • The Dock-Cities – The fortified mountain settlements that managed commerce and passage between the sky and the land.

  • The Outer Provinces – The agricultural and mining regions, sustaining the empire’s economy and supplying its war machine.

  • The Border Forts – Strongholds that marked the limits of the empire, guarding against both foreign invaders and internal dissent.

docs.title: Modes of Travel
docs.text:
• Sky-Galleons – Vast airships that connected floating cities to the land, powered by arcane propulsion.

  • Imperial Roads – Enchanted highways that allowed swift and efficient movement between the empire’s key holdings.

  • Drake-Carriages – Beasts of burden bred for speed and endurance, serving nobility and military officers alike.

docs.title: Travel in the Empire
docs.text: Imperial decree strictly controlled access to its floating cities. Entry required sanctioned writs, granted only to merchants, scholars, and officials. The dock-cities managed trade and migration, ensuring that only those deemed worthy ascended to the skies.

docs.title: Entry and Reentry
docs.text:
• The Gilded Arch – The grand entrance to the imperial capital, a gate of obsidian and gold, guarded by elite sentinels.

  • The Azure Gateways – The enchanted portals that linked the floating cities, accessible only by those who held the emperor’s favor.

  • The Iron Watch – The heavily fortified border gates, defending the empire’s most vulnerable frontiers.

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
• Aetherstone – The foundation of the floating cities, an arcane mineral infused with levitational properties.

  • Blacksteel and Obsidian – The primary materials of imperial construction, resilient and imposing.

  • Glasscrete – A fusion of volcanic sand and enchanted binding agents, forming the empire’s transparent yet unyielding structures.

docs.title: Development
docs.text: The mastery of Empir Draconi’s arcanists and engineers saw the birth of an age of unparalleled innovation. In the later centuries of the Gnosichron Era, the empire undertook its most ambitious endeavor: the separation of mountaintops from their earthly roots, shaping them into great floating cities sustained by aetherstone and tethered to the arcane fabric of the world. These airborne bastions did not replace the island kingdom but instead served as mobile strongholds, centers of governance, and testaments to the empire’s command over both magic and nature. Below them, dock-cities emerged at the severed peaks, vital trade hubs linking the heavens and the land.

docs.title: Landmarks
docs.text:
• The Magisterium Spire – The seat of arcane governance, where scholars and artificers dictated the advancement of magical sciences.

  • Locations/Settlements/Draconic Empire/Establishments/The Sunforged Coliseum – A grand arena where warriors proved their worth before the emperor’s gaze.

  • The Riftvault Archives – A subterranean vault containing ancient knowledge, accessible only to the empire’s most trusted minds.

docs.title: Climate
docs.text:
Beneath the empire’s cities and fortresses, the land thrived under careful cultivation and arcane augmentation:

  • A temperate climate, stabilized through controlled weather manipulation.

  • Seismic activity harnessed for geothermal energy and volcanic glass production.

docs.title: Environment
docs.text:
Flora

  • Aetherbloom – A luminous flower cultivated for its arcane-conductive properties.

  • Obsidian Vines – Hardy plants used in the reinforcement of imperial walls and terraces.

Fauna

  • Drakebeasts – Domesticated wyvern-like creatures serving as the empire’s primary aerial mounts.

  • Ember Stags – Flame-touched cervids revered as omens of imperial favor.

Pests

  • Void Moths – Insects that consume residual arcane energy, weakening enchantments over time.

  • Burrow Leeches – Subterranean parasites that infest the lower districts and outer provinces.

docs.title: Symbolism
docs.text:
(Emblem/Crest)

A dragon’s eye surrounded by an intricate, spiraling pattern, representing [[The Arras]]. The color of the eye shifts depending on the magical alignment of the ruler.

Mascot

The Argent Wyrm – A legendary silver dragon believed to have been The Weaver’s first emissary. Though its existence is debated, it remains a powerful symbol of legitimacy for any emperor.

docs.title: Settlement Leaders
docs.text:
Though Empir Draconi was an empire, governance was handled by a council of magisters and appointed officials under the emperor.

  • The Emperor – A dragon ruler believed to be the avatar of The Weaver. Their reign was marked by both reverence and political intrigue.
  • The Magisterium – A council of twelve arcane scholars and statesmen who oversaw the empire’s laws, research, and elemental affairs.
  • The Warden of [[The Arras]] – A single archmage dedicated to maintaining balance in magic and ensuring the stability of the empire’s leyline-based infrastructure.
  • The High Talon – The supreme commander of the empire’s military forces, often a dragon or draconic warlord.
Legislation

docs.title: The Mandates of Dominion
docs.text:
The Codex Imperius

A series of laws dictating the hierarchy of rule, the upkeep of magic, and the empire’s doctrine of expansion. Any challenge to the Codex was considered heresy, punishable by death or exile to the Kagecombs.

docs.title: Factions
docs.text:
Empir Draconi was rife with internal factions, each vying for control, knowledge, or survival in the empire’s tumultuous political landscape.

The Weaversworn (deceased)

A religious order dedicated to interpreting The Weaver’s will, often clashing with the Magisterium over the balance of faith and arcane study.

The Wyrmforged (deceased)

An elite group of enchanters and smiths who created Empir Draconi’s greatest magical artifacts, including the floating cities.

The Ashen Pact (deceased))

A secretive cabal of dragons and magisters who sought to break the empire’s rigid hierarchy and place magical prodigies in power, regardless of bloodline.

The Taloncloaks (survivors today)

An imperial intelligence network specializing in espionage, assassination, and political manipulation. Their true allegiance often shifted with the tides of power.

The Riftborne (active)

Individuals who were permanently altered by exposure to [[The Arras]]’s instability. Many of them escaped to the Kagecombs after the fall, forming splinter communities of warped mages and outcasts. These outcasts and exiles studied the unstable remnants of [[The Arras]] during the [[Tenechron]], believing that understanding its flaws could lead to a second age of floating cities.

docs.title: Crime
docs.text:
Empir Draconi’s society was highly regulated, with magic itself being one of the most controlled resources. However, many underground movements sought to subvert, steal, or weaponize arcane power.

  • Soulforging – The illegal practice of binding souls into magical objects, creating immensely powerful relics at a horrific cost.
  • Fabric Piracy – Smugglers who harnessed unstable leyline currents to transport goods and fugitives.
  • Blood Rituals – Forbidden dark magic involving dragon or draconic-blood sacrifices, rumored to enhance a sorcerer’s power.
  • Artifact Theft – The Magisterium heavily monitored magical artifacts, but rogue scholars and thieves often sought to claim lost relics for their own gain.
  • Coup Conspiracies – Political intrigue was a way of life, and entire networks existed to overthrow rulers or install puppet leaders.

docs.title: Adaptation to Threats
docs.text:
Empir Draconi stood as a bastion of power, yet it was not without its dangers. The empire’s survival relied on an intricate network of defenses, both mundane and arcane. To guard against external forces and internal subversion, the Magisterium commissioned legions of warding glyphs and arcane surveillance systems. Enchanted fortifications ensured that even the floating cities were protected from siege, with arcane storms conjured to repel aerial assaults.

The empire faced threats beyond mortal warfare—fabric rifts, incursions of eldritch entities, and rogue sorcery tested its resilience. The Warden of [[The Arras]], an imperial office charged with maintaining stability between the Material and Astral planes, was pivotal in preventing such disasters. Specialized orders, such as the Riftwardens and the Ashen Pact, were established to combat existential threats.

Natural disasters were no less perilous. The empire's island heartland was prone to tremors and seaquakes, leading to extensive research in seismic mitigation. Floating cities were engineered not merely for expansion, but as a safeguard against these cataclysms, ensuring that the ruling elite could govern unscathed even if the land below suffered.

docs.title: Arcane Integration
docs.text:
Magic was the lifeblood of Empir Draconi, interwoven into its culture, industry, and warfare. The empire’s architects employed geomancy and elemental binding to construct and sustain its great cities. Roads pulsed with leyline energy, ensuring swift travel, while archaic golems carried out labor alongside mortal craftsmen.

The state maintained strict oversight of arcane practice, with the Magisterium regulating the use of leyline tapping and to what extent. The Weaversworn, a prestigious sect of spellcasters, were entrusted with grand arcane endeavors, from stabilizing the floating metropolises to imbuing imperial relics with untold power. Meanwhile, the Wyrmforged—mage-smiths of unparalleled skill—crafted living metal constructs, automated sentinels that patrolled the empire's borders.

Even daily life bore the mark of magic. Farmers called upon weatherbinders to ensure bountiful harvests, while healers infused their remedies with restorative enchantments. Those of noble blood often bore sigils of protection, their ancestral lines marked by contracts with spirits or celestial patrons.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text:
The empire was deeply spiritual, its doctrine a fusion of ancestor veneration and celestial worship. The Weaver, an enigmatic cosmic entity believed to shape fate itself, was revered above all. Temples of the Grand Loom stood as places of worship and divination, where oracles deciphered the threads of destiny.

Imperial cults flourished, dedicated to revered emperors who had ascended beyond mortality. Pilgrims sought blessings at the tombs of past rulers, believing that their spirits guided the empire from beyond the veil. In contrast, the Riftborne—esoteric sects that communed with the chaotic forces beyond [[The Arras]]—were viewed with suspicion, their practices teetering on the edge of heresy.

docs.title: Holidays
docs.text:
• Aeternis Reckoning – The new year’s celebration, marking the passage of another cycle within the empire’s grand chronicle. Rituals of renewal were performed, and the emperor’s decree for the coming year was unveiled.

  • The Celestial Weave – A holy festival honoring the divine tapestry of fate. Oracles presented prophecies, and citizens wove symbolic threads into grand murals representing their aspirations.

  • Titanfall Remembrance – A solemn day of reverence for the empire’s victories over the primordial giants in the Titanfall Conflict. Military parades and historical reenactments honored the legacy of those who fought.

  • The Night of Shattered Veils – A time of caution, marking the anniversary of a near-catastrophic planar breach. Protective wards were reinforced, and offerings were made to the Warden of [[The Arras]] to maintain balance between realms.

docs.title: The Magisterium of Empir Draconi (Pre-1354)
docs.text:
• Archmagister Thalvorius the Adamant - A revered scholar and master of elemental transmutation, Thalvorius was one of the last voices of caution before Vethiskaar's Folly. He sought to stabilize [[The Arras]] but was ultimately silenced by the emperor's decree.
  • Magister Iridessa Vhalar - A brilliant artificer who specialized in aetherstone technology. Some of her surviving blueprints hint at undiscovered secrets of levitation magic.
  • Magister Rylthorne the Vexed - Known for his controversial research into the fusion of draconic essence with mortals, Rylthorne's experiments were outlawed, but rumors suggest his work continued in secret enclaves.

docs.title: The Riftborne Survivors (Post-1354)
docs.text:
• Veylin "Ashcloak" Draevan - A former sky-noble turned warlord, Veylin commands one of the strongest enclaves within the Docking Rings, leading scavengers in reclaiming lost arcana from the fallen empire.
  • Orvessa the Hollow-Eyed - A mystic who wandered into the Kagecombs and returned with cryptic knowledge. She claims to hear the whispers of the empire’s lost souls.
  • Jaspar Flintwing - A courier and wind-skiff pilot who specializes in navigating the Wastes of Draconi, offering passage and illicit trade between scattered enclaves.

docs.title: The Chain of the Rift (Cult of the Fallen Empire)
docs.text:
• High Seer Kaelith Morryn - Leader of the Chain, a sect that believes the empire's destruction was divine punishment for their hubris and seeks to bind the shattered world in servitude to a higher order.
  • Inquisitor Zareth Vox - A ruthless enforcer of the Chain’s doctrine, known for hunting down rogue arcanists and apostates in the ruins.
  • Elder Drenmar Thalvos - An ex-Magister who repurposed his knowledge of [[The Arras]] to serve the Chain, creating rituals designed to suppress the lingering magical anomalies of the empire.

docs.title: Historical Figures
docs.text:
Empress Vorrashka the Skyborne (r. 512-588)

One of the few non-draconic rulers in the empire’s history, Vorrashka was a storm genasi whose command of elemental magic earned her a throne among the empire’s elite. Her rule is remembered as a golden age of interplanar diplomacy.

Emperor Kael’Zyrrith the Gilded (r. 764-829)

Known for his economic and territorial expansion, Kael’Zyrrith transformed Empir Draconi into a center of elemental commerce. His reign saw the construction of the first floating cities.

Magister Ulthara the Everbound (r. 899-955)

A scholar of immense renown, Ulthara uncovered a means of stabilizing floating cities using Aetherstone resonance, but mysteriously disappeared in a diplomatic mission to the elemental planes.

High Talon Serevaal the Blackened (d. 1021)

A legendary warleader who waged campaigns against rogue giant enclaves in the southwestern mountains. His tactics in aerial warfare became the foundation of Empir Draconi’s military doctrine.

Vethiskaar the Last (d. 1354)

The final emperor of the Arcane Draconic Empire, Vethiskaar attempted to extend his dominion by manipulating [[The Arras]] to control elemental forces. This catastrophic experiment led to the collapse of his empire and the onset of the elemental storms that defined the Tenechron. His name is now synonymous with hubris among arcane scholars.

docs.title: Trade Partners
docs.text:
• The Aetherbound Consortium – A powerful mercantile network that specialized in the trade of arcane materials, rare metals, and enchanted textiles. Their airships frequently docked at Empir Draconi’s floating cities, exchanging resources for exclusive access to the empire’s aetherstone reserves.
  • The Myrmidic Holds – A collection of fortified enclaves along the empire’s eastern frontier, known for their exceptional craftsmanship in weapons and armor. Empir Draconi relied on their metallurgy and, in return, provided protective enchantments and air transport.
  • The Pearl Cities of the Azure Coast – A federation of seafaring city-states that engaged in the trade of exotic spices, aquatic alchemy components, and luxury goods. The empire exchanged enchanted constructs and navigational artifacts for their maritime expertise.
  • The Obsidian League – A shadowy yet influential trade network that dealt in rare artifacts, alchemical reagents, and contraband. Though officially denounced by the empire, many within its nobility relied on their smuggling operations to circumvent trade restrictions.

docs.title: Allies
docs.text:
• The Skyward Compact – A coalition of floating city-states that aligned with Empir Draconi in mutual defense, technological exchange, and cultural collaboration. Their bond ensured shared advancements in aerial navigation and levitation magic.
  • The Covenant of Dawn – A religious order devoted to celestial phenomena, whose healers and diviners worked closely with the empire’s magisters. Their alliance bolstered the empire’s spiritual legitimacy and access to divine magic.
  • The Argent Dominion – A knightly order dedicated to preserving ancient relics and protecting arcane knowledge. Their warriors often served as elite guards in Empir Draconi’s highest courts and arcane academies.
  • The Ember Pact – A diplomatic agreement between fire-wielding elemental clans and the empire, ensuring cooperation in energy production, warfare, and trade of rare volcanic minerals.

docs.title: 1. Vorthessar & Vorthasdral
docs.text:
• Vorthessar (Floating) – Known as the “Crown of the Magisters,” this city was home to the most prestigious arcane academies and research sanctums. It housed the Magisterium’s grand council chambers, where laws were debated and the empire’s magical advancements were overseen.
  • Vordral (Docking) – A fortified settlement built into the mountain base, Vordral served as the gateway to Vorthessar, hosting alchemical markets, smithies specializing in arcane-infused weaponry, and diplomatic lodges for emissaries.

docs.title: 2. Xiranthessar & Xirandral
docs.text:
• Xiranthessar (Floating) – A stronghold of the empire’s military elite, Xiranthessar functioned as a mobile command center, allowing rapid deployment of imperial forces. Its sky-docks were lined with drake-rider garrisons and warforged constructs, ready for battle at a moment’s notice.
  • Xirandral (Docking) – A rugged outpost carved into the cliffs below, Xirandral was a recruitment hub, prison complex, and proving ground for warriors. Its infamous gladiatorial pits tested potential conscripts in brutal combat trials.

docs.title: 3. Zevorithessar & Zevoridral
docs.text:
• Zevorithessar (Floating) – The heart of commerce and trade, Zevorithessar’s shimmering marketplaces were famed across the empire, dealing in rare goods, magical artifacts, and luxury wares. Merchant princes wielded immense influence here, competing for imperial favor.
  • Zevoridral (Docking) – A heavily defended checkpoint ensuring only authorized traders could access Zevorithessar. It was also a haven for spies and clandestine dealings, as ambitious merchants often sought to undercut rivals through underhanded means.

docs.title: 4. Aerynthessar & Aeryndral
docs.text:
• Aerynthessar (Floating) – Revered as the “City of Saints,” Aerynthessar was the spiritual center of Empir Draconi, where high priests communed with celestial forces and the doctrine of the empire’s divine mandate was solidified.
  • Aeryndral (Docking) – A sprawling sanctuary and pilgrimage site, Aeryndral housed shrines, temples, and healing wards where both the faithful and the desperate sought solace or divine intervention.

docs.title: 5. Dravethessar & Dravedral
docs.text:
• Dravethessar (Floating) – An industrial and technological marvel, Dravethessar was home to the empire’s most advanced forges and artificer workshops. The city pioneered soulforging techniques and produced enchanted armaments of unparalleled craftsmanship.
  • Dravedral (Docking) – A mining and labor settlement that supplied raw materials to Dravethessar’s forges. Populated largely by skilled laborers and bound artisans, Dravedral was the backbone of the empire’s weapon production and infrastructure.

docs.title: Enemies
docs.text:
• The Titansworn Clans – The remnants of the giants who waged the Titanfall Conflict, seeking vengeance against the draconic rulers for their ancient war crimes. They frequently raided imperial territories and disrupted trade routes.
  • The Gloamborn Rebellion – A secretive insurgency that opposed the empire’s expansionist policies and arcane exploitation. Their agents worked from the shadows, sabotaging imperial projects and inciting uprisings among the oppressed.
  • The House of Ash – A rogue faction of exiled Draconi nobles and arcane dissidents who sought to reclaim lost power through subterfuge and assassination. They maintained hidden enclaves in distant lands, plotting their return.
  • The Umbral Dominion – A rival empire that vied for control over arcane ley lines and forbidden knowledge. Their necromantic overlords viewed Empir Draconi as both a threat and a prize to be conquered.

docs.title: Neighbours
docs.text:
• The Verdant Principalities – A loose confederation of forested kingdoms to the west, known for their deep druidic traditions and reluctance to engage with Empir Draconi’s arcane pursuits. Trade existed, but tensions over deforestation and resource exploitation remained high.
  • The Sunken Halls of Nythra – An ancient subterranean civilization dwelling within the Kagecombs, whose relationship with the empire was one of cautious diplomacy. Their expertise in abyssal magic and underground navigation made them valuable allies and dangerous foes.
  • The Stormforged Bastions – Mountain strongholds inhabited by tempest-wielding warrior clans, some of whom served as mercenaries while others actively resisted imperial expansion.
  • The Whispering Sands Confederacy – A desert-dwelling network of nomadic tribes that controlled key trade routes across the former seabed. Their neutrality made them indispensable as guides, but their loyalty was never guaranteed.

docs.title: Language
docs.text: Empir Draconi boasted a rich linguistic tradition, with Draconic serving as the official language of governance, magic, and high culture. However, regional dialects and influences from trade partners and vassal states contributed to a diverse linguistic landscape.

docs.title: Dialects and Accents
docs.text:
• High Draconic – The formal dialect spoken by the ruling elite, scholars, and magisters. This version was infused with arcane phrasing and complex grammatical structures.
  • Imperial Common – The lingua franca of the empire, derived from Draconic but simplified for ease of use among traders, artisans, and commoners.
  • Dockside Creole – A blend of Imperial Common, regional tongues, and foreign influences, spoken in trade hubs and docking settlements.
  • Deep Cant – The dialect of those who fled to the Kagecombs, heavily influenced by underground survivalist slang and cryptic phrasing meant to conceal meaning from outsiders.

docs.title: Developmental Impacts
docs.text:
The expansion of floating cities and subterranean enclaves influenced every aspect of Empir Draconi’s social structure. The wealthy and powerful resided in elevated cities, looking down—both literally and figuratively—on those in the docking settlements below. Meanwhile, the island kingdom, which served as the heart of the empire, became a highly stratified society where proximity to the emperor often dictated political influence.

With the fall of the empire, the survivors’ adaptations led to further divergence in culture and daily life. Those in the wastes maintained vestiges of imperial grandeur, while the Kagecombs’ denizens developed a pragmatic and secretive society, valuing adaptability and communal survival over status and tradition.

docs.title: Cuisine
docs.text:
• Skyborne Feasts – Lavish meals consisting of rare meats, exotic fruits, and spiced wines, reserved for the floating city elites.
  • Seafarer’s Fare – Fresh seafood, preserved kelp, and fermented delicacies were staples for those on the island kingdom before its sinking.
  • Dockside Stews – Hearty meals made from accessible ingredients like root vegetables, dried meats, and sea salt.
  • Wasteland Rations – In the post-collapse world, foragers rely on roasted drakegrass, ember vine fruit, and smoked storm drake meat.
  • Kagecombs Brews – Distilled from underground fungi and bioluminescent algae, these potent drinks are both nourishment and ritual offering.

docs.title: Rich/Poor Gap
docs.text: Wealth disparity in Empir Draconi was pronounced. The aristocracy resided in floating palaces of aetherstone, removed from the struggles of common laborers. The merchant class, while influential, still relied on imperial favor to maintain their status. Below them, dock workers, farmers, and artisans lived under strict economic hierarchies. Following the empire’s fall, the survivors saw a forced equalization—those who retained knowledge of imperial technology or arcane secrets held an advantage, while former elites struggled to adjust to the new world order.

docs.title: Outsiders
docs.text:
Empir Draconi maintained a wary stance toward outsiders, balancing diplomacy with displays of strength.

  • Allied Traders – Merchant guilds from neighboring regions were permitted controlled access to docking settlements but rarely allowed into floating cities.
  • Vassal Tribes – Some indigenous peoples were assimilated into the empire, while others resisted, leading to ongoing conflicts.
  • Arcane Scholars – Foreign mages sought entry to study the empire’s advances in magic, though few were granted permission without proving loyalty.
  • Post-Fall Relations – In the wake of the empire’s collapse, survivors in the wastes and Kagecombs remain suspicious of newcomers, viewing them as potential threats or resources to exploit.

History and Lore

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Description

Hellhaven is a sprawling city located at the eastern edge of Locations/Regions/Loierr Fenest, where the fjord meets the Locations/Regions/Windbor Coast. Founded in 1933, it became the epicenter of human theocracy, built upon the arrival of both humans and their god. The city serves as both a seat of power and a beacon of divine influence, with towering temples and dark spires dominating the skyline. Hellhaven’s streets are a mix of industrialization, religious fervor, and societal control, reflecting both the power of [[The Lord]] and the struggles of those living under his rule. Despite its oppressive atmosphere, Hellhaven remains a thriving hub of political and religious activity, drawing citizens and refugees alike seeking to live under the strict doctrine of [[The Lord]].

Hellhaven’s history is one of divine governance, military dominance, and a slow shift from the natural to the imposed. Once, the land was fertile and lush, but now it bears the scars of overuse and divine exertion. The city's buildings rise tall, made from black stone and wrought iron, often shrouded in a perpetual haze from residual Tenechronian magic that permeates the air.

Hellhaven is considered a [[Settlement Classification Chart#^bafa77|Metropolis]].

Residents

Hellhaven is a city of devout followers and those desperate enough to seek refuge within its walls. Its population is primarily composed of humans, with a significant number of military personnel, clergy, and administrative officials. [[Concordat of Chains|The Concordat of Chains]] holds the most power, serving as both enforcers of divine law and elite military agents. The lower classes often live in fear, working in the factories or serving the clergy in menial ways.

Some come to Hellhaven out of necessity—many by birth, others by the will of [[Concordat of Chains|The Concordat]], and some seeking salvation or answers from [[The Lord]]. However, dissent is brewing beneath the surface. Underground movements and secret alliances work to resist the city’s divine control, though they are largely unsuccessful due to the ever-watchful eye of the [[Creosmagi]].

While Hellhaven is a city of faith, it is also a place of secrecy, danger, and political intrigue, where the line between devotion and manipulation is often blurred.

Demonym: Hellian

Species Contour
  • Humans (50%)
    • Standard, Fey-Descended Humans, Half-Elves, Shifters
  • Kagefolk (15%)
    • Dwarves, Gnomes, Drow
  • Fae (10%)

  • Hybrids (10%)

  • Minority Groups (10%)

History and Lore

The history of Hellhaven is closely tied to the city’s foundation being built on a newfound gift of calming storms; Gellhafn. Over time, Gellhafn became a mercantile giant, but its power base later shifted from a port town to a sprawling city-state ruled by the clergy and military.

During the later years of the city’s formation, tensions arose between the mercantile elites and the [[Concordat of Chains]], both seeking to claim authority of Gellhafn. These tensions came to a head during after The Dread, when Gellhafn’s political climate shifted to give credit to the Creed of Blinding Light, now willing to believe that a higher power was communicating through global catastrophe to express dissent about magical regulation.

Despite these challenges, Gellhafn become Hellhaven, who still survives, though city life is constricted through both religious fervor and mercantile control. The city’s infrastructure became more complex, with the creation of the [[Creosmagi]] as both a religious police force and a military arm of [[The Lord]]’s divine will. Today, Hellhaven stands as a symbol of divine rule and unwavering order, although beneath its holy exterior lies a web of political intrigue and hidden rebellion.

docs.title: Atmosphere
docs.text: Dark and Heavy: The air is thick with a sense of saltwater and incense, accompanied by the constant hum of religious rituals. The scent of burning offerings lingers in every corner, and the oppressive weight of divine oversight hangs over the city like a perpetual storm cloud.

docs.title: Populace
docs.text: Devout and Subjugated: The citizens of Hellhaven live under a strict theocracy, their lives governed by [[The Lord]]’s will. Religion and governance are inseparable, and almost every aspect of daily life is influenced by the city’s devout clergy. Despite this, there are murmurs of dissent among the more oppressed and disenfranchised groups, though open rebellion is rare due to the constant surveillance and control of the Inquisitors. Resilient but Fearful: The people of Hellhaven have learned to live with fear and reverence, constantly watching their actions, thoughts, and words. The deep piety instilled by the church is a double-edged sword—while it provides a sense of purpose and unity, it also stifles any attempts at self-expression or deviation from the divine law. Class Divisions: The city is deeply divided into classes, with the clergy and military occupying the highest echelons, while the common folk serve in subjugation to [[The Lord]]'s divine will. The lower classes are relegated to menial tasks, working the factories and serving the wealthy, while the elite enjoy the privileges of power and influence.

docs.title: Rapport
docs.text: Enforced Piety: Hellhaven is renowned for its unwavering dedication to [[The Lord]]. Its citizens are constantly reminded of their place within the divine order, with the clergy acting as the primary enforcers of religious law. The Inquisitors, a military and religious police force, patrol the city, ensuring that no one deviates from the prescribed teachings and practices. Cultural Repression: Hellhaven’s culture is one of strict obedience to [[The Lord]]’s will. Festivals and celebrations are rare, often occurring only during holy days or the anniversaries of significant religious events. Even then, they are imbued with solemnity and reverence, lacking the joy or exuberance found in other cities. Secretive underground movements occasionally attempt to overthrow the established order, but they are always stamped out swiftly by the ruling authorities. Power Struggles: While outwardly Hellhaven appears unified under the rule of [[The Lord]], there are political struggles between various factions of the clergy and military. These factions vie for influence and power, and while they may outwardly present a united front, there are deep fractures within the system that often lead to covert power struggles. Religious Sanctity: Despite its oppressive nature, Hellhaven is a pilgrimage site for those seeking divine enlightenment or wishing to prove their devotion to [[The Lord]]. Pilgrims travel from across the land to pay homage to [[The Lord]]’s temples, seeking blessings or guidance, often unaware of the city’s darker underbelly.

docs.title: Quick Facts
docs.text:
• Front: A reputable tinkering and repair shop specializing in ship components, automaton parts, and fine clockwork mechanisms. The sign outside reads: “Brighton’s Fix & Fiddle – Precision Repairs & Custom Craftwork.”
Overview
  • Location: Nestled in a dimly lit alley of the Chainmoor Brine Yards, squeezed between a rotting sailmaker’s loft and a derelict spice warehouse. The constant clatter of gears and hissing steam conceal hushed conversations.
  • Access: Customers seeking more than mechanical repairs must use the coded phrase: “I need a tune-up for my arcane conductor.”—only then will Brighton lead them into the hidden chamber below the shop.
  • Hidden Chamber: A vaulted, sea-sprayed cavern beneath the shop, where arcane trinkets float weightlessly in lantern-lit glass cases. Some items still hum with residual magic, while others seem eager to be held.
NPCs History and Lore
  • True Business: A black-market magic emporium dealing in stolen and cursed magical items, often plundered from merchant caravans.

docs.title: Brighton the Proprietor
docs.text: Brighton, an Archfey warlock with an unsettling grin, runs the shop. Always impeccably dressed, with clockwork jewelry that shifts on its own, he speaks in riddles and deflects questions with humor. Those who cross him tend to vanish into the dark tides of the Chainmoor.
