docs.title: ~ Society and Culture
docs.text: Perched between mountain shadow and sea-glow, Sauztein Geb is a fractured marvel—a city that dances on the bones of old tectonics, scavenges from the sky, and sings through spindled glass and lattice. Suspended across terraces, lifted platforms, and partially restored aerial shards, it thrives by salvaging, inventing, and reimagining. Mnemonic magic flows through its infrastructure, infusing memory with matter, craft with cognition. A haven for flight-specialists, scavenger guilds, and memorysmiths, Sauztein Geb is known as much for its ingenuity as for its volatility.

docs.title: Atmosphere
docs.text: A tang of ozone and rusted lightfract clings to the air, layered with the scent of hot stone, chemical brine, and flowering highwind moss. You hear the hum of gliders overhead, the hiss of memory distilleries venting steam, and the irregular toll of seismic stabilizers echoing from deep shafts below. There’s movement everywhere—carts, cranes, skyferries, and windwalkers on wired boots.

docs.title: Populace
docs.text: The people of Sauztein Geb move with purpose and a kind of collective half-focus, always multitasking, often mid-construction. Mages scribble glyphs into the air with silver styluses while tinkerers dangle upside-down from broken beams. Conversation is fast, technical, and oddly poetic. Memory-tattoos flicker across bare shoulders, and flight gear is common garb even among shopkeepers.

docs.title: Rapport
docs.text:
To outsiders, Hausztieners seem distracted, curt, or even paranoid—especially when discussing resource scarcity or Fabric instability. But those who stay long enough to prove they’re not saboteurs or thieves are often adopted quickly into small, fierce social circles bound by projects and shared trauma. Knowledge is traded like coin. Secrets less so.

Residents

Demonym: Hausztieners

Species Contour

While mostly elfin, Sauztein Geb is home to sky-blooded faerfolk, wind-bound elementals, and memory-born constructs known as Recallants—once-mortal minds bound to crystal bodies or mechanical frames. Goblin presence is limited post-Dreka Goro’s secession but still found in enclaves near the lower lifts.

History and Lore

Pronunciation: sow-stine gehb Meaning: Crystal's Bounty

Archaic Iterations:

  • Don Morcoux

    • Pronunciation: dohn mohr-coo

    • Meaning: The Gift of Chaos' End

    • An old name carried in prophecy-laced texts discovered in the vaults beneath the Riftglass Plateau, once believed to mark the final stabilizing node of a shattered continent. Replaced by "Sauztein Geb" after the rediscovery of the Crystal Wellspring and the establishment of mnemonic binding tech.

docs.title: Invention
docs.text:
Sauztein is one of the most innovation-forward cities in the Council due to its access to lightfract, a living crystal network that amplifies mnemonic and temporal magics. Invention here is not just mechanical—it is psycho-arcane. Artificers, scribe-smiths, and echo-forgers work in experimental harmony with memory-sourced blueprints, often creating devices that already remember how they should function.

The Chronoscribes regulate dangerous invention by locking volatile designs behind Mnemonic Seals, which require synchronized minds to access. Smuggled blueprints are often encrypted in dreamscapes.

docs.title: Distribution
docs.text:
• Lightfract Veins: Controlled by the Spirehands Guild and taxed by the Council.

  • Memory Crystals (Aetherlace): Allocated under Council permits, regulated by the Chronoscribes.

  • Filtered Echoresin: Distributed by the Hollow Choir's intermediaries to shadow-markets and low-tier inventors.

docs.title: Imports
docs.text:
• Nutrient Slabs & Synthmeals from Hellhaven Concord.

  • Binding Alloys & Fracture-Alloys from Winbor Coast refineries.

  • Soulglass Components from Drosvenna’s arcane salvage.

  • Fresh Minds—conscripted or “volunteered” individuals for memory-labor.

docs.title: Income
docs.text:
• Export of stabilized Lightfract Shards and temporal-laced relics.

  • Licensing Council-backed mnemonic prosthetics.

  • Illicit trade in blackmarket memory snippets and loop-sculpting art.

  • Council’s interest subsidies on experimental containment tech.

docs.title: 🏭 Key Industries
docs.text:
Mnemonic Crafting

Creation of memory-based devices, temporal stabilizers, emotion-charged tools, and recall tokens. Used in both medicine and warfare.

Lightfract Resonance Tuning

The refinement and shaping of Sauztein’s native crystal into usable infrastructure or psycho-reactive tech.

Memory Dredging & Loop Containment

Salvage and repair of timeline fractures. Recovery agents are trained to navigate nonlinear events and extract stable chrono-matter.

Echo-Engineering

Arcane-construction based on sound, harmonics, and memorywave attunement. Used to grow buildings, machines, and even sentient architectures.

Mind-Sculpting & Dreamsmithing

A luxury and blackmarket art—crafting or rewriting memories and personality shards for clients. Technically illegal unless licensed.

docs.title: 🎭 Niche Professions
docs.text:
Time-Attuner

Tunes personal devices to a user’s chronostability. Prevents unintentional duplication, collapse, or loop fragmentation.

Loop-Weaver

Designs stable microloops to preserve environments, art, or personalities in fixed-time scenarios. Sometimes hired to create haunted installations.

Shard-Daemonist

Specialist in semi-sentient crystal formations. Often bonded to a Lightfract warden-beast for urban maintenance.

Memurgeon

A surgeon who manipulates emotional and temporal scars instead of physical wounds. Used for trauma removal or espionage resets.

Echo-Sealer

Creates echo-null zones to shield areas from memory or time bleed. Common in high-security or ritual spaces.

Cognition Broker

Middlemen who trade memory-snippets, often customizing narratives for customers’ personal myths, trauma therapy, or addiction.

Dreamwright

Elite artisan hired to construct fully immersive mnemonic landscapes, often for mourning, inspiration, or rehabilitation.

docs.title: 🧱 Mundane Professions
docs.text:
• Shaft-diggers

  • Crystal scrapers

  • Meal-batch fermenters

  • Walkwind mechanics

  • Civic beacon-harmonizers

  • Talisman engravers

  • Rail pathers

  • Lightfract haulers

  • Shardstreet vendors

  • Loop-menders (low-tier field agents)

docs.title: Companies
docs.text:
1. Lucid Helix Consortium Logo: A silver helix inscribed with runes around a fractured core. A semi-legal mindscaping firm that supplies high-end memory loops and fabricated lives to clients. Suspected to have ties to Dredger guild defectors.

2. Vaexial Harmonics Ltd. Logo: A tuning fork piercing a prism, radiating sound-lines. Official partner of the Spirehands Guild. Manufactures resonance tools and echo-safe materials. Funds public infrastructure projects.

3. The Sabled Guild Logo: A single blindfolded eye over a memory crystal. Elite Cognition Brokers operating in plain sight. They own parts of Shardmarket and sponsor underground artists who work with looped art or grief-vaults.

4. Synthread Corp. Logo: Interlocked memory tags forming a braid. Producers of memory prosthetics and narrative healing kits. Works with the Council in veterans’ clinics and trauma centers.

5. Choir of Iridescent Scar Logo: A cracked mirror wrapped in luminescent thorns. A front-company for the Hollow Choir’s mind-distribution wing. Officially distributes filtered lightfract and chant-infused talismans.

docs.title: Planning
docs.text:
Sauztein Geb was not built in a traditional fashion—it grew, much like the resonant crystal that pulses through its foundations. Original settlements were small mining alcoves, later interlinked by harmonic scaffolding grown from Spirehand designs. Over centuries, neighborhoods emerged around resonance nodes, forming an uneven but reactive sprawl.

The city is semi-subterranean, tiered into crystalline hollows, shaft-cities, and resonance chambers, most of which follow the natural flow of the lightfract veins. Above ground, shattered crystal towers glimmer under dim skylight, while the true life of the city pulses deeper within.

docs.title: Districts
docs.text:
Core Districts of Sauztein Geb include:

  • Irid Vaults – The memory archive halls run by the Chronoscribes. Part library, part fortress, and part prison of unwanted pasts.

  • The Rootflumes – A living architectural region where Spirehands guide crystal-growth to house residential needs. Constantly shifting and humming with latent energy.

  • The Loamshaft – Lowest legal district before collapse zones; flooded with filtered lightfract. Home to poor laborers, smugglers, and dredgers.

  • The Upper Chime – Council-garrisoned plateau above the city. Host to administration towers and the eerie Resonance Bell, which tolls only during echoquake warnings.

  • Shardmarket – The volatile commerce center built atop cracked resonance. Street stalls sell memory-snippets, soulcrystals, dredged relics, and forged futures.

  • Hollow Choir Cloisters – Secretive, crypt-like sanctums carved into forgotten veins, used for sermons and synchrony by the Choir's followers.

docs.title: Modes of Travel
docs.text:
• Latticerails – Thin levitating tramways that “slide” via attuned harmonic pulses. Dangerous if mistuned—can trigger memory echoes.

  • Crystaspires – Vertical lifts powered by vibrational tuning forks. Sometimes fall into feedback loops during city-wide resonance flux.

  • Walkwinds – Subterranean walkways reinforced with echo-barriers to prevent cognitive spill. Many are privately guarded.

  • Chimebeasts – Semi-domesticated fauna bred for resonance navigation, used mostly in Loamshaft areas. Glimmer-skinned and eerily silent.

docs.title: Travel in the City
docs.text:
Navigating Sauztein means avoiding zones of high echo saturation, where time distorts or fractures may occur. Citizens carry memory tags—inscribed talismans tied to their current moment—to anchor their consciousness in linear flow.

Certain paths shift when the city re-harmonizes weekly, meaning maps must be updated constantly by the Spirehands and Chronoscribes.

docs.title: Entry and Reentry
docs.text:
Entry to the city requires passing through Mnemonic Clearance Points, where:

  • Your surface memory is scanned for hostile echoes or illegal grafts

  • Visitors are assigned a “Reverence Anchor,” a mind-stabilizing charm

Reentry is harder. Citizens who’ve been outside too long are subject to drift, where memory becomes misaligned. The longer you're gone, the more you may forget where you belong.

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
• Resonant Crystal (lightfract, amberglas, shadestone)

  • Echo-etched Limestone

  • Boneglass (calcified, infused with sonic runes)

  • Rootmetal Filament – organic alloy grown from fungal-metal hybrid veins

Structures are partially sung into form by choir-architects or molded through vibration-sculpting.

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
Each building evolves with the needs of its inhabitants—walls bend subtly over time to accommodate emotional frequencies, and “echo doors” may open only when specific memories are thought of.

Districts sometimes shift their boundaries overnight during harmonic tremors. These events are called Veinbursts.

docs.title: Landmarks
docs.text:
• The Irid Archive Spindle – A shimmering monolith that spirals down 13 levels, housing centuries of recorded memory.

  • The Resonance Bell – Ancient crystal bell suspended over a fracture nexus. Its toll stabilizes the city... or shatters it further.

  • Mirror Hollow – A fault-pocket of pure mnemonic bleed, where visitors see versions of themselves that never existed.

  • The Lattice Cairn – A Spirehand memorial, pulsing gently with the death-harmonies of those who shaped the city’s veins.

  • The Nullspire Column – A condemned pillar of crystal where memory cannot exist. Used for exile or purification rituals.

docs.title: Climate
docs.text:
Sauztein Geb exists within a filtered geoluminal basin—light does not behave normally here. There is no traditional day-night cycle, but rather pulses of photonic bloom and luminous decay, both of which affect memory coherence.

Air is dry but thick with particulate resonance. Winds hum. Echostorms occasionally tear through sectors, leaving behind memory-slick surfaces and spectral afterimages.

docs.title: Flora
docs.text: Crystawheat – Edible shard-grain grown under false-light. Tough but sustaining. Glowfane Ivy – Climbs walls and lights districts at night, but may remember the voices it hears too often. Vireling Bloom – A fragile flower said to grow only where deep memory is buried. Used in mourning rites.

docs.title: Fauna
docs.text: Chimebeasts – Docile, vibration-sensitive mounts used by lower dwellers. Lurkrill – Insectoid tunnel scavengers, feast on memory-fragments. Dewdancers – Tiny glider-creatures made of silk and dust. They feed on psychic residue.

docs.title: Pests
docs.text: Shardmice – Glass-bodied rodents that gnaw through mindglass for warmth. Sometimes steal stray memories. Resonance Wasps – Aggressive creatures that inject mnemonic venom. Victims experience looping thoughts or false pasts. Nullmolds – Fungal infections that erase history from buildings and people alike. Dangerous and hard to detect.

docs.title: Symbolism
docs.text:
Emblem/Crest

A fractured prism set within a stylized eye, ringed by thirteen concentric lines (each representing a failed collapse prevented by Council intervention).

Mascot

“The Whisperwren” — a small, glass-winged bird believed to nest in harmonic flares. Its song is used to detect unstable memory pockets before they rupture.

docs.title: Settlement Leaders
docs.text:
Governance in Sauztein Geb is tripartite, but imbalanced: the Council’s presence dominates, local guild authority struggles for autonomy, and spiritual influences subtly manipulate beneath the surface.

  • [[Queen Liraenne du Virelys]] The current monarch of Sauztein Geb, descended directly from the astral elven line of Don Morcoux. Regal, inscrutable, and known for her radiant presence, she wears the Opalescent Crown with both grace and quiet dread. Rumors suggest she communes with something within the oldest ruins beneath the palace.

  • Overpréfet Cerid Banlot (Crystallis Council Spokesperson) Wields veto power over major legislation and coordinates Concord military deployment. Pragmatic, detached, and views the city as a crystalline fuse waiting to blow.

  • Guildmistress Thaerila Vennarienne (Chronoscribes Leader) Enforces memory legislation, manages the Irid Archive, and oversees the use of sanctioned mnemonic technologies.

  • High Resonant Tellun Sar (Temple of the Crystalline Veil) Spiritual authority across resonance rites and rituals; not officially part of governance, but his sermons are studied like law.

  • Magistrate Jessa Truanne (Civil Order & Mediation) Oversees court systems and inter-faction disputes; known for being both just and deeply exhausted.

Legislation

docs.title: Resonance Conduct Law (controls access to crystal harmonics, public rituals, and sound-emission technologies)
docs.text:
The Harmonic Limitation Decree (A.R. 1257)

Restricts public use of high-frequency resonance tools (like tuning-staves or harmonicscanners) due to their potential to:

  • Agitate unstable crystal networks

  • Trigger latent memory loops

  • Interfere with Concord communication nodes

Exceptions granted to certified Spirehands and Temple Chimebearers.

The Refractive Disturbance Accord

Signed between Concord enforcers and local guilds to regulate:

  • Mining methods near resonant crystal veins

  • Ritual song frequency use

  • Timing of public choral rites

Breakage leads to both fines and civic memory re-alignment (often forced reflection therapy).

Amendment 13-C: The Public Echo Curfew

Establishes a nightly curfew during which memory dredgers and resonance technicians must halt all operations. Why? Because during twilight and night hours, crystal matrices become volatile — leading to a higher chance of phantom projections (unintentional memory specters) and temporal bleed.

docs.title: Memory Regulation Doctrine (governs dredging, scribing, memory-trading, and identity preservation)
docs.text:
Directive on Mnemonic Property Rights

Defines ownership of one’s own memory. It’s illegal to: - Sell another’s memories without notarized consent - Embed false memories in mindglass without disclosure - Copy or fracture a “soul-sequence” for duplication or entertainment

Ethics Charter for Temporal Dredgers

A training and licensing document. Mandates: - Consent protocols before scanning someone’s past - Mindfield containment measures during echoquakes - Maximum allowed “temporal dip” duration before cognitive feedback risk

The Mindglass Confidentiality Mandate

Criminalizes: - Leaking memory-snippets from the Irid Archive - Using dredged memories as legal evidence without cross-verification - Storing weaponized trauma-imprints in public archives

Also enforced by the Council under civil security statutes. Violations can lead to memory erasure or exile to the Nullspires.

docs.title: Factions
docs.text:
The Chronoscribes

Time-law enforcers and memory archivists. Power centers in the Irid Archive.

The Spirehands Guild

Crystal-shapers and infrastructure builders. Control Rootflume architecture.

The Temple of the Crystalline Veil

Keepers of resonance theology. Their doctrine shapes public rituals and holidays.

The Undergleam Kin

Radical rebels, secessionists, and echo-sick outcasts. Hidden in the lower shafts.

The Lightfract Smugglers

Blackglass and resonance dealers. Control the illicit “emotional experience” market.

The Concord Representatives

External governors and military supervisors from Hellhaven. Prioritize resource security over local lives.

docs.title: Crime
docs.text:
Despite Concord surveillance, crime is rampant and often sonic, mnemonic, or metaphysical in nature.

  • Blackglass Trafficking: Illegal trade of volatile scrying crystal. Powers resonance heists and prophetic terrorism.

  • Echo Theft: Stealing identity-fragments from others, often resold to dream dens or used to forge artificial selves.

  • Fracture Poaching: Entering unstable zones without a dredging license to scavenge memory relics.

  • Resonance Sabotage: Weaponizing harmonic pulses to cause structural collapses or public auditory hallucinations.

  • Soulloop Sculpting: Creating illegal mnemonic loops for luxury reliving or torturous punishment.

docs.title: Current Threats
docs.text:
• The Echoquake Instability Fragmented temporal echoes have begun to resonate uncontrollably beneath the Rootflumes and Old Galleries, leading to localized time fractures, memory bleed, and spontaneous loopzones. Some areas have collapsed inward, pulling structures into unanchored pasts or futures.
  • The Hollow Choir A rogue sect of former Chronoscribes who worship the Echo Unformed—a theorized entity composed of untethered memories. They seek to deepen the fractures, believing full collapse will allow communion with a “pure astral self.” Hollow Choir operatives infiltrate rituals and sabotage stabilization engines.
  • Crystal Plague (“Refraction Sickness”) Caused by prolonged, unbuffered exposure to unstable lightfract crystals, this affliction leads to physical crystallization of tissue, sensory overload, and echo-induced psychosis. Though treatable if caught early, poor districts often delay care.
  • Lurkers Beneath the Gleaming Hollow Miners whisper of serpentine things glimpsed in reflective facets deep in the mines—mirror-skinned horrors that move without sound and eat memories instead of flesh. Reports increase every cycle.

docs.title: Adaptation to Threats
docs.text:
• Ward-Tuning and Echo Anchoring Civil engineers and mages specialize in pulsebound stabilization, a method of anchoring locations with rotating ley beacons and mnemonic wards. Neighborhoods pay tribute to guilds for regular re-tuning.
  • Crystal Licensing Handling of raw lightfract or “live resonance cores” requires certification. Unauthorized possession is punishable by exile or memory stripping (performed ritually by sanctioned Chronoscribes).
  • Memory Dredgers A public service caste tasked with recovering and reintegrating displaced memories caused by echo-slip. They act as emergency responders during fractures and occasionally work with lawkeeping bodies to verify testimonies through memory-stitching.
  • The Writ of Soft Treading A societal code practiced during unstable cycles—movement slows, conversations soften, and all wear non-reflective coverings. Crystals are dimmed to reduce harmonic agitation.

docs.title: Arcane Integration
docs.text:
• Architecture & City Planning Entire sectors are constructed with ley-etched foundations that “breathe”—pulsing in time with the city’s arcane lattice. Buildings are grown from crystal grafts, shaped by artisan-mages called Spirehands.
  • Everyday Magic
    • Glimmglyphs: Minor household enchantments etched in walls to create light, warmth, or sound muffling.
    • Echocharms: Worn to protect against memory slippage; usually set with a loved one's voice or a stabilized moment.
    • Public Transit: Involves short-range aether folds, which teleport passengers across fixed points via stabilized space-threading paths.
  • Chronoscript Law All official documents must be time-stamped magically, ensuring the moment of signing is stored within the page itself. Legal disputes often involve recalling and witnessing the moment of contract creation through magical replay.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text:
• The Lattice Divine (The Crystalline Veil) The dominant spiritual belief system sees divinity in interconnected patterns—not beings. Followers of the Veil believe all thought, matter, and time form an ever-shifting pattern that can be read through resonance, meditation, and prism-scrying.
  • Temples Called Vescaries, these crystal domes are tuned to amplify ley-song. Worship is often silent, focused on internal resonance rather than external veneration. Religious leaders are known as Resonants, and their status is tied to how clearly they can “hear” the universal lattice.

docs.title: Holidays
docs.text:
• Lumenwake A celebration of the year’s first full harmony pulse from the central Spire Core. Citizens hang lightfract wind-chimes and engage in ritual stillness to “catch the perfect moment.”
  • Echofall A memorial season when the veil between moments thins. People wear masks of those they've lost or were in past lives, and memory offerings (engraved on crystal shards) are sent down the Gleaming Hollow river.
  • The Silent Ring Once a century, the entire city falls quiet for three days, acknowledging the moment Sauztein Geb first heard the astral lattice. It's both a holy observance and a massive calibration of all magical infrastructure.

docs.title: The Opal Court & Council
docs.text:
• [[Queen Liraenne du Virelys]] – The current monarch of Sauztein Geb, descended directly from the astral elven line of Don Morcoux. Regal, inscrutable, and known for her radiant presence, she wears the Opalescent Crown with both grace and quiet dread. Rumors suggest she communes with something within the oldest ruins beneath the palace.

  • [[Archmagus Thévain d’Aurelac]] – Master of Arcane Conservation, responsible for studying, interpreting, and preserving the Novachron glyphs within the ancient stonework. Quiet and pale, with opal-veined eyes and a delicate touch with magic that seems to bend time.

  • [[Butler Alistelle de Lioranne]] – Noble representative of the fertile southern fiefdoms. Known for her charm, decadent salons, and politically dangerous gossip. Her allegiances shift like tides, but she always lands on her feet.

  • [[Comte Vaurien de Rochambre]] – Lord of the highland mines, his family manages the extraction of precious minerals from the crystal-laced caverns. Gruff and utilitarian, he sees the monarchy as sacred but believes in the strength of coin above all.

  • [[Seigneur Marné Vallisque]] – Merchant king of Sauztein Geb’s opal and spellglass trade. Wears rings laced with raw aural energy and speaks in glowing economic prophecy. Some suspect he’s secretly funding an arcane monopoly.

  • [[Chevalière Ylisse Dornévant]] – Commander of the royal guard, known as the Shardsworn. Stoic, battle-scarred, and unshakably loyal to the Queen, but whispered to have a personal vendetta against the swamp-dwellers of Hly’draug.

  • [[Victoire Nemevalle]] – High Priestess of the Luminous Echo, Sauztein Geb’s primary faith centered around ancestral resonance and starlight memory. Gentle in tone but utterly ruthless in rooting out corruption or false divination.

  • [[Maître Cerelune Briavell]] – Representative of the artisan caste and guild leader of the Weavers of Prismatic Craft. Wields enormous influence through enchanted fashion, memory-infused sculpture, and dream-distilled perfumes.

  • [[Warden Thrannic Delmarr]] - Grey dwarven Prince of Dwelreach, heir to the Delricht throne, and sole reason for the end of the Auroral Vein Dispute. Spends most of his time under soft guard in the Crystalseal Pavilion, but is present during public-facing events as a reminder to the Opal Court's power and influence.

docs.title: The Chronoscribes (Arcane archivists of memory and time)
docs.text:
• [[Archivist Elenvoir Morchaude]] – Stoic and prismatic-eyed, she leads the Chronoscribes from the Irid Archive. Known for her emotionless clarity and capacity to recall exact seconds from centuries ago.

  • [[Scribe-Lieutenant Jome Aethern'e]] – Oversees Echoquake containment; rumored to be experimenting with illegal mnemonic grafting tech to predict future fractures.

  • [[Memorist Vel Curneaux]] – A low-ranking scribe who illegally sells memory-snippets to black market artisans and memory dens. He seeks redemption—or at least escape.

docs.title: The Undergleam Kin (Tunnel-dwelling rebels and outcast communities)
docs.text:
• [[Rin "Coalcut" Marrev]] – A former Spirehand who turned revolutionary after her brother succumbed to Refraction Sickness due to poor zone management in the lower shafts.

  • [[Tahlin "Le Langue'eclat"]] – Prophet of the Hollow Choir’s fringe sect; his body is laced with growing, living crystal. Preaches a coming moment when “all time shall hum in one note.”

  • [[Maedren Skellieu]] – Smuggler of filtered lightfract for poor districts. Hates the Council for its exploitative mining practices and sabotage of memory dredgers.

docs.title: Spirehands Guild (Arcane builders and crystal-shapers)
docs.text:
• [[Maitre-Tailleur Alvix Dorneux]] – Oversees structural reshaping of the Rootflumes. Respected for his architectural genius, but slowly losing cohesion due to prolonged exposure to raw harmonics.

  • [[Apprentice Lurelle Vauxl'e]] – A prodigy who hears the lattice’s “whispers.” Secretly being courted by both the Council’s elite and the Hollow Choir.

  • [[Ruthen Bexot]] – Overseer of residential Spire-growth. Blunt, practical, deeply concerned about unstable districts, and suspected of passing info to the Undergleam Kin.

docs.title: The Crystallis Council Representatives (Governors, diplomats, and enforcers from the Hellhaven Concord)
docs.text:
• [[Overpref'et Cerid Banlot]] – Political liaison from Hellhaven. Believes Sauztein Geb is expendable if the crystal instability spreads.

  • [[Magistrate Jessa Truanne]] – A Council enforcer sympathetic to the city’s citizens. Maintains order with minimal violence, but her leash is shortening.

  • [[Dainhardt Glimmerung]] – Secretly part of the Ironwreath Syndicate. Posing as a Concordist official while mining influence, literal and metaphorical.

docs.title: Memory Dredgers (Recovery agents and first responders for echo-fractures)
docs.text:
• [[Draguer Ilim Myrthe]] – Famous for rescuing a whole district from loop-collapse. Carries dozens of stored memories not his own, and it's wearing thin.

  • [[Tessari Drahme]] – Works in the poor rings, often for free. Was once a scribe but now refuses to speak except in mnemonic glyphs.

  • [[Rokk Denlire]] – Veteran dredger with a mechanical arm fitted with tuning forks and harmonizers. Hates the Spirehands for abandoning his collapsed family zone.

docs.title: Lightfract Smugglers & Blackglass Dealers
docs.text:
• [[Vain "Mirrorcut" Solen]] – Dandy-like thief and rogue scholar of resonance. Collects rare reflections and forgotten timelines like trophies.

  • [[Casseth Orlun]] – Runs an illegal “memory bar” where clients relive curated emotional experiences. Ex-scribe with a price on her head.

  • [[Yvette Farv]] – Imports blackglass (unstable crystal used for scrying), and distributes it across unstable sectors to “accelerate the truth.”

docs.title: Temple of the Crystalline Veil
docs.text:
• [[High Resonant Tellun Sartre]] – Beloved spiritual leader who once sang a resonance so pure it stalled an entire collapse. Now fading, literally—phasing in and out of the moment.

  • [[Echo Sister Pryll]] – Enforces doctrine with unsettling serenity. Believes silence is sacred and often speaks through lightfract-script or gesture.

  • [[Vicar Jonrith Daiveux]] – A rising priest-artist who “paints with sound,” creating audible mosaics in public prayer domes.

docs.title: Historical Figures
docs.text:
Elvar'e “The Aegistone” Threnne

The first to stabilize a resonance fracture using only her voice and a cracked staff of lightfract. Died singing into the Gleaming Hollow.

Marnak Voleux

Founder of the Spirehands Guild, built the original Rootflumes by shaping them mid-collapse. Vanished into a prismatic fold; supposedly still alive in a pocket second.

The Marbled Prophet

An ancient Hollow Choir visionary whose body calcified into flawless crystal during a ritual. Her skull still hums under specific frequencies.

General Cassan Derrielle

Led the city's defenses during the Veilfire Uprising. Slaughtered echo-mutated Opalguard troops and then erased the memory of it citywide.

Raevaine Calloush

The Council-appointed arbiter who once ordered the memory-wipe of an entire caste. Sparked the schism that formed the Undergleam Kin.

docs.title: Trade Partners
docs.text:
• [[Drosvenna]] – A floating market city of scavengers, aerial tinkerers, and skybound mages. Trades in flight tech, scavenged relics, and modular skycraft parts.

  • Locations/Settlements/TO BE FLESHED/Dreka Goro – A coastal enclave shaped by goblin culture. Exports strange sea-bound spices, jury-rigged devices, and salt-dried reagents.

  • Locations/Settlements/TO BE FLESHED/Bo Renn – A rugged mining town at the base of the western mountains. Offers refined minerals, raw ore, and low-cost labor contracts.

  • Locations/Settlements/TO BE FLESHED/Cuirefyn – A northern roadside village nestled in the hilly plains. Renowned for herbal remedies, rare medicinal plants, and eco-alchemy supplies.

docs.title: Allies
docs.text:
• The Skywake Accord: An alliance of aerial trade pilots and mercantile dirigibles who favor Sauztein Geb for repairs and enhancements.

  • Vraekholdt: A high-perched cliffside settlement once nearly buried in a Fabric quake. Hausztiene engineers helped stabilize the cliff lattice, forging a bond of gratitude and joint seismic research.

  • Mirequay: A fortified, fog-wreathed town along the southern coast. Their reliance on modified Hausztiene filtration tech to cleanse their salt marshes led to lasting cooperation.

  • Tasselreed: A lowland agrarian commune where Hausztiene alchemists once helped contain a crop rot plague with memory-infusion techniques. Now a reliable source of raw alchemic staples.

  • Brasshearth Bastion: An isolated forge-city with deep volcanic roots. Shares experimental metallurgy secrets with Sauztein Geb in return for heat-resistant latticework and energy stabilizers.

docs.title: Enemies
docs.text:
• The Hollow Choir (Fringe Sect): Particularly the crystal-obsessed zealots who wish to dissolve Sauztein Geb into resonance.

  • The Ironwreath Syndicate: Criminal infiltrators aiming to siphon resources, sabotage governance, and weaponize mnemonic magic.

  • The Ravine Corsairs: Sea-raiders who occasionally make inland runs for lightfract and memory graft tech.

  • The Gleamscour: A radical eco-purist faction who blames Sauztein Geb’s existence for unbalancing the Fabric and unleashing Echoquakes.

  • Locations/Settlements/Ironbound Dynasty/Dwelreach: An underground empire of miners who blame Sauztein Geb's deep-lattice projects for a series of devastating echoquakes that collapsed half their mines, and blocked them off from extracting their ancestral birthright: the lightfract veins.

docs.title: Neighbours
docs.text:
• Yennoc’s Spine: A vertical settlement clinging to a rift in the southern cliffs; trades in smoked fish, oil-glass, and fissure-grown gems.

  • Klev’Sorn: A nomadic plain-fair town that migrates across the northern hills with great wheeled platforms, bartering seasonal produce and crafts.

  • Xereth Vale: A distant, isolationist society nestled deep in the western mountain fold. Rarely interacts, but tales speak of ancient resonance stabilizers and forgotten lattice scripts.

  • [[Harrowfen]]: A mist-laden village at the fjord's eastern bend, known for prophetic mushroom cults and soft diplomacy. Maintains a wary but non-hostile distance. One of the main southern Kagekunan entrances.

  • Nauzeret Strand: A coastal fishing settlement to the southeast with drifting trade barges and a superstition-laced view of Sauztein Geb's skytech as omens.

  • Fenbramble Reach: A northern marshbound commune using earth-speech and vinecraft; often called upon to assist with botanical anomalies in Hausztiene infrastructure.

docs.title: Dialect and Accents
docs.text:
• High Eltheric (Eltherai Valucien): The formal, ceremonial language used in law, academia, and governance. Rooted in astral phonetics, High Eltheric is spoken with elongated vowels, harmonic inflections, and rhythmic patterns that mirror the cadence of leyline pulses. Words may contain silent pauses—intentional gaps meant to reflect "lightbreath" (a tradition of respectful silence).
  • Low Eltheric / Crystal Cant: A more conversational dialect blended with miner's shorthand, artisan lingo, and borrowed dwarvish terms (especially among tradesfolk and the crystal-guild caste). It carries clipped consonants and occasional tonal shifts, developed for clear speech in echo-chambers and under ambient resonance from crystal structures.
  • Accents:
    • Corelight Accent: The elite nobility of the upper towers speak with a fluid, almost musical cadence—softened consonants, vowel glides, and astral harmonics threaded into daily speech.
    • Hollowtone: Those living closer to the deep roots or echo-choked quarters have speech patterns that emphasize guttural stops and echo-dampened syllables, reflecting environmental necessity.
    • Ridgecracked Drawl: A rugged tone common among boundary rangers and tradefolk along the Shiverpath—infused with dwarvish diphthongs and harsh cadence for overland or tunnel shouting.

docs.title: Developmental Impacts
docs.text:
• Magic as Infrastructure: The widespread use of lightfract crystals and ley conductors has created a city where even the poor enjoy some ambient luxuries—like warmth from lumenveins or crystallight in common thoroughfares. However, education in arcana is highly stratified, limiting who can truly wield or understand the deeper workings of the city.
  • Time Perception: Due to astral echoes and the cultural respect for fragmented memory, many inhabitants adopt a non-linear view of time. The past isn’t "gone"—it’s present, accessible, even dangerous. This affects planning, emotional development, and historical education. Children are taught to interpret and not fear echo-anomalies.
  • Echobound Professions: Citizens often choose vocations based on family “echoline,” studying recorded memories or echo-glimpses of ancestors to “inherit” skills. Some trades rely entirely on this, particularly Glasswrights, Opalbinders, and Chronoscribes.

docs.title: Cuisine
docs.text:
• Crystal-Grown Produce: Underground gardens nourished by lightfract channels yield bioluminescent fungi, vine-fruits like telari pearls, and root-honey tubers.
  • Meat & Protein: Predominantly insectoid protein (from shimmercrabs and ley-burrowers), riverfish, and imported herding beasts from upland elfholds. Sauztein cuisine avoids heavy seasoning, instead highlighting textures and luminosity—a dish should glow, sing, or fracture in the mouth.
  • Common Delicacies:
    • Shattermoss Soup: A clear broth with crystal-flecked algae that pops and fizzes softly.
    • Auroral Caviar: From dreamfish caught near the Gleaming Hollow.
    • Whispercake: A dessert made from spun sugarroot and essence-capture, traditionally eaten in silence.

docs.title: Rich/Poor Gap
docs.text:
• Subtle Stratification: The wealth divide is reflected in elevation. The higher one lives in Sauztein Geb, the more access they have to stable echoes, clean crystal resonance, and ambient aether. The poor live in the Rootflumes, a district near unstable echo zones and sediment buildup.
    • Upper Castes: Fluent in High Eltheric, taught crystalcraft, often wear lightwoven garments that shimmer in tune with their heartbeats.
    • Lower Castes: Work as Refractors (echo stabilizers), Wickrunners (crystal maintainers), or Siltbearers (transporting unstable crystal runoff). They dress in grounding fabrics threaded with lead-pins or damping rings to avoid echo sickness.
  • Notably: Basic living standards are still relatively high due to crystalline infrastructure—no one starves, but opportunity is tightly controlled by caste and access to sanctioned arcana.

docs.title: Outsiders
docs.text:
• Dwarves of the Kagecombs: Viewed with tense respect. Dwarves are often seen as blunt and “too rooted,” but their mineral knowledge is unmatched. Many elves quietly envy the dwarves' resistance to echo influence.
  • Humans: Treated as dangerously fast-living and culturally reckless. Their short lifespans and rapid development cycles disturb the city’s measured pace. A human’s presence often signals trade, war, or theological confusion.
  • Drifters & Echoborn: Individuals with unknown origins who wandered in from unstable time fissures. Treated with suspicion, sometimes reverence. Many echo-priests believe them to be testaments from the Astral Collapse—living prophecies, or dangerous paradoxes.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Description

Located within the south edge of the Locations/Landforms/Glistening Canopy, Vrellyn is north of Locations/Regions/Hly'draug, east of the Locations/Landforms/Twin Rivers, and west of the Locations/Landforms/Drakonspyne Mountains.

Vrellyn dates back to the [[Gnosichron]], making it several thousand years old. Its history is marked by periods of abandonment and renewal, particularly during the plagues and conflicts with Hly'draug.

Despite its age, Vrellyn has continuously evolved, incorporating new architectural styles and technologies, while preserving its ancient roots and cultural traditions.

Vrellyn is considered a [[Settlement Classification Chart#^82a8df|City]].

Notable Residents

People come to live in Vrellyn either by inheritance, or to seek its medical wonders. The pharmaceutical sciences are most advanced in Vrellyn, so the sick congregate here to find fabled cures to their varying illnesses. Additionally, there are those that come to study medicine, botany, biogolemancy and physiology. Between the college and its location within the Locations/Landforms/Glistening Canopy, its residents are highly diverse and welcoming towards the Faeriefolk, so those who would escape the oppression of Locations/Settlements/Haven of Hale/Hellhaven or the lands of shadow beyond the Locations/Landforms/Drakonspyne Mountains.

The locations/Settlements/Verdant City/Districts/Hivedrums provide a thriving environment of black market exchanges of dangerous and experimental drugs, as well as deadly poisons and other concoctions sought out by [[Umbrea]]'s finest assassins and contract killers.

Residents of Vrellyn take on the demonym "Vrellian".

[!note]- Species Contour - Faeriefolk (50%) - Bearfolk, Erina, Ratatosk, Cervan, Jerbeen, Mapach, Strig, Vulpin, Tortle, Grung, Lizardfolk, Aarakocra, Harengon - Animate Plantfolk (20%) - [[Vine-tender]], [[Mossling]], [[Sapling]], [[Fungoid]] - Druidic Elves (15%) - Bosmer, Genasi, Satyr, Centaur, Fairy, Goblin, Hobgoblin, Bugbear - Dwarves (10%) - Hill Dwarf, Duergar - Minority Groups (5%) - Fey-Descended Humans (2%) - Half-Elf, Shifter, Changeling, Kalashtar, Vedalken, Quickstep - Gnomes (1%) - Forest Gnomes, Rock Gnomes, Svirfneblin - Orcs (1%) - Orc, Half-Orc - Titanblood (1%) - Kobold, Dragonborn, Yuan-ti, Goliath

History and Lore

The first settlers of the area were further south, along the border of Locations/Regions/Hly'draug during the [[Gnosichron]]. Before the swamp was infested by infection, it was a thriving ecosystem of medicinal flora and awakened fauna. In fact, it was one of the few locations in which the ancestors of the ancient race of treants resided. Their collective wisdom of the area attracted druidic priests and healers, whose services attracted the accumulation of a community.

The proximity to the swamp during the initial period of infection caused there to be an outbreak of [[The Plague]], which is an early iteration of the symptoms occurring from fungal infection from the Locations/Regions/Kagecombs. The settlement was quarantined and abandoned, leaving the meager few who appeared to be uninfected to find shelter within the Locations/Landforms/Glistening Canopy. The ancient treants were unable to escape with the rest of the town, but they imparted a final incantation unto the druids, who would later use it to reinforce the Locations/Landforms/Glistening Canopy from the spread of the Locations/Regions/Hly'draug.

This settlement was abandoned a second time during the [[Tenechron]]. Most residents found their way towards settlements far away from old locations/Settlements/Verdant City/Vrellyn, including a large group that traveled northwest to find the Locations/Regions/Kagecombs marshland below Locations/Settlements/TO BE FLESHED/Cuirefyn. Other storm refugees from Locations/Settlements/Opalescent Spires/Sauztein Geb and Locations/Settlements/TO BE FLESHED/Irrhilm discovered a large cavern below the Locations/Landforms/Glistening Canopy, where a stream empties into the caverns below. The appeal of this location was not only its access to relatively fresh water, but also the occasional shafts of sunlight that would reach through the Tenechronian storm clouds and down the stream entrance. This settlement would become a permanent extension of the modern city of locations/Settlements/Verdant City/Vrellyn.

docs.title: Atmosphere
docs.text: Fresh and Humid: The air in Vrellyn is fresh, filled with the scent of herbs and flowers, and carries a natural humidity due to the dense vegetation. The bioluminescent plants and fungi contribute to a faint, pleasant glow in the evenings, creating a soothing atmosphere. Magically Purified: Thanks to the Vrelline Air Masks and filtration systems, the air is kept clean and free from harmful spores. These systems use enchanted plants to filter out toxins, ensuring a safe breathing environment despite the proximity to Hly'draug.

docs.title: Populace
docs.text: Innovative and Adaptive: Vrellians are known for their ingenuity, blending magic and nature to solve problems. They are adaptive, finding ways to thrive in a challenging environment. Community-Oriented: Despite the class divisions, there is a strong sense of community and mutual responsibility, especially during festivals and crises. Mystically Inclined: Many citizens have a natural affinity for magic, and even those not formally trained often use minor magical charms or enhancements in daily life. Resilient: Shaped by their history of plagues and threats, Vrellians are resilient and resourceful, with a deep respect for both tradition and innovation.

docs.title: Rapport
docs.text: Pharmaceutical Expertise: Renowned for its advanced medicinal products, sought after across the continent. Biogolemancy: Pioneering the creation of autonomous, plant-based golems. Cultural Festivals: Notably the Festival of Vital Bloom, which draws attention for its unique blend of celebration and education.
